Introduction.html.title: Introduction
Introduction.html.body:
Introduction
libreact is a collection of most essential React utilities you will probably need in any project.
Render prop and FaCC notation is used interchangeably as most libreact
components support both interfaces. Also, most render prop components support
component prop interface, with the following precedence:

FaCC
Render prop
Component prop

Render props
Render props are components which have props that start with render* and accept a function that
returns a React element, for example:
 }
  renderBody={() => }
  renderFooter={() => }
/>

Where the function like () =>  "renders" the navigation.
Typically though a render prop component will have only one render* prop, in that case
we simply call it render.
 } />

FaCC
FaCC or Function as a Child Component is a special case of render prop where the single
render prop is called children instead.
 } />

FaCC notation is superior to a single render prop notation, because you can put the rendering function into props, as
above, or place it as a child in JSX tree, which allows your "HTML" markup to have natural spacing.
{({posX, posY}) =>
  
}

FaCCs are especially convenient when you use hyperscript function h to create your
React elements, because you don't have to type the closing tag and create a props object unnecessarily.
h(MouseSensor, null, ({posX, posY}) => h('div')})

Component prop
Component prop is when a component expects a component or comp prop that
itself is a component.



libreact supports both ways of component prop (comp and component). Normally, when a component has a
render prop interface it will also support the component prop interface.
HOC
HOC or Higher Order Component is a function that receives AND/OR returns React components.
Enhancer
Enhancer is a HOC that receives AND returns React components.

Dummies.html.title: Dummies
Dummies.html.body:
Dummies
Dummies are empty "shell" components that don't contain the actual implementation.
However, those dummies can be used as real React components and they will re-render
automatically once they get implemented.
Essentially you can create dummies, which will not add any size to your bundle, use them,
but implement them with real components only later when necessary.

mock() - dummy that can be implemented using .implement() method.
loadable() - dummy that can be loaded using .load() method.
lazy() - like loadable(), but also loads automatically when rendered for the first time.
delayed() - like lazy(), but its loading can be delayed.
viewport() - postpones component's rendering until it is visible
in viewport at least once.

mock.html.title: mock()

loadable.html.title: loadable()

lazy.html.title: lazy()
lazy.html.body:
lazy()
Creates a loadable() component which is loaded automatically when it is rendered for the first time.
Use it exactly the same as loadable(), the only difference is that it will automatically .load() on first render.
However, you still have access to the .load() method, which allows you "pre-load" your components ahead of time.
Reference
lazy: (params: ILazyParams) => React.ComponentClass;

interface ILazyParams extends ILoadableParams {}

delayed.html.title: delayed()

viewport.html.title: viewport()

Inversion.html.title: Inversion
Inversion.html.body:
Inversion

inversion
the action of inverting something or the state of being inverted.

Inversion is a technique where one injects state and/or life-cycle methods into a render prop.
This effectively allows you to have

State
Life-cycle methods
Refs to DOM elements
Other objects

in JSX tree without having to write stateful React components.

invert() and  — inverts DOM element ref.
 — inverts .state and .setState() method.
, , , , , and 



Example
A basic example, cnt is incremented by 1 on each click

  {({cnt}, set) =>
     set({cnt: cnt + 1})}>
      {cnt}
    
  }


or the same using  component
{({value, inc}) =>
  
    {value}
  
}

invert.html.title: invert()

Sensors.html.title: Sensors
Sensors.html.body:
Sensors
Sensors are render pros that track some behavior and re-render on state change.
For example, the below  will be re-rendered every time mouse position changes.

  {({posX, posY}) => }


libreact comes with plenty of sensors built-in.

 — tracks battery status.
 — tracks device geographical location.
 — tracks element's hover status.
 — tracks media devices connected to your device.
 — tracks matches of a media query.
 — tracks physical motion of your device.
 — tracks mouse position inside an element.
 — tracks network connectivity and type state.
 — tracks physical lightning sensor state.
 — tracks browser location.
 — tracks physical device orientation.
 — tracks scroll offsets in a DOM element.
 — tracks child DOM element size.
 — same as , but only re-renders on width change.


 — tracks elements visibility in viewport.
 and 


 — tracks window scroll position.
 — tracks window size.

Most sensors have also corresponding HOC and class decorator that provide the same functionality.
For example,  render prop component has a corresponding withNetowrk() HOC and
@withNetwork decorator.

ScrollSensor.html.title: ScrollSensor
ScrollSensor.html.body:
ScrollSensor
FaCC that re-renders on when scroll position in a DOM element changes.
Props

el - HTMLElement whose scrollTop and scrollLeft to track.

Example
import {ScrollSensor} from 'libreact/lib/ScrollSensor';

{({x, y}) =>
  `x: ${x}, y: ${y}`
}

SizeSensor.html.title: SizeSensor

WidthSensor.html.title: WidthSensor
WidthSensor.html.body:
FaCC that works similar to  but re-renders only on width change.
Example
Use it as FaCC
import {WidthSensor} from 'libreact/lib/WidthSensor';

{({width, height}) =>
  `WIDTH: ${width}, HEIGHT: ${height}`
}

Or use onWidth prop
import {WidthSensor} from 'libreact/lib/WidthSensor';

 console.log(width, height)}>
  Resize me!


withWidth() HOC and @withWidth decorator
Works same as withSize() and @withSize.
Incldue withWidth as follows
import {withWidth} from 'libreact/lib/WidthSensor';

Context.html.title: Context
Context.html.body:
Context
libreact provides a range of component's that use React's context API and components that allow you
to easily use React's context.

 and  — utilities to work with React's context.
 and  — theme provider and consumer.
 — provides ability to use CSS variables today.
, , and  — best router for React.
 and  — translation provider and consumer.

LocalStorage.html.title: LocalStorage
LocalStorage.html.body:
Uses Window.localStorage API to persist value in local storage.
Usage
import {LocalStorage} from 'libreact/lib/LocalStorage';



 {/* ... */}} />

Props

name - key name on localStorage object.
data - data to store, can be a plain JavaScript object.
persist - optional boolean, that indicates whether to leave the value in localStorage when
your component unmounts. By defaults the stored local storage value is removed once the coponent is
un-mounted, set it to true to leave the value on un-mount.
debounce - optional, time in milliseconds how often to persist to localStorage on re-renders, this
value can be set only once on initial render.
onMount - optional, callback that receives stored data on component mount. Useful to persist and
re-hydrate form data, for example.

Example
In the below example form inputs are stored in localStorage and re-hydrated when user
comes back and form renders for the first time.

   this.setState({name: e.target.value})}
  />
   this.setState({email: e.target.value})}
  />
   this.setState(state)}
  />

Speak.html.title: Speak
Speak.html.body:
Speak
Read out loud provided text.
Props

text - string of text to read.

Example
import {Speak} from 'libreact/lib/Speak';

Vibrate.html.title: Vibrate
Vibrate.html.body:
Use navigator.vibrate() to generate
device vibrations.
Props

ms - time in milliseconds for how long to vibrate. Can be a single number, or an array of numbers.
If array of numbers is specified, every second value is used a vibration lenght and values in between
are considered pauses between the vibrations.

Example
import {Vibrate} from 'libreact/lib/Vibrate';

Alert.html.title: Alert
Alert.html.body:
Uses Window.alert() to display message to a user.
Usage
import {Alert} from 'libreact/lib/Alert';



Props

show - boolean, optional, whether to show the alert.
text - string, require, string message to display to the user.

Boundaries.html.title: Boundaries
Boundaries.html.body:
Boundaries
Boundaries are components that split the element tree — its ancestors and children —
according to some semantic meaning.

 — renders children only in browser.
 — renders children only on server.
 — renders children only in an Electron app.
 — reports errors in its children.

BrowserOnly.html.title: BrowserOnly
BrowserOnly.html.body:
Component that renders its children only if used in browser environment.
Usage
import {BrowserOnly} from 'libreact/lib/BrowserOnly';


  
    You can see this only in browser.

ServerOnly.html.title: ServerOnly
ServerOnly.html.body:
Component that renders its children only if used on a Node.js server.
Usage
import {ServerOnly} from 'libreact/lib/ServerOnly';


  
    You can see this only on server.

ElectronOnly.html.title: ElectronOnly
ElectronOnly.html.body:
Component that renders its children only if used in an Electron app.
Usage
import {ElectronOnly} from 'libreact/lib/ElectronOnly';


  
    You can see this only if Electron app.

UI

 — provides mouse position inside element when scrubbing.

CSS-resets.html.title: CSS resets
CSS-resets.html.body:
CSS Resets
CSS reset components  provide a handy way to include CSS reset in your app.
You simply need to render the css reset component somewhere in your JSX tree for it to take effect.
import CssResetEricMeyer from 'libreact/lib/reset/CssResetEricMeyer';

const App = () =>
  
    
    { /* ... */ }
  

When you un-mount a CSS reset component it will also remove the CSS automatically.
Below is a list of included CSS resets.

reset/CssResetEricMeyer.html.title: CssResetEricMeyer

reset/CssResetEricMeyerCondensed.html.title: CssResetEricMeyerCondensed

reset/CssResetMinimalistic.html.title: CssResetMinimalistic

reset/CssResetMinimalistic2.html.title: CssResetMinimalistic2

reset/CssResetMinimalistic3.html.title: CssResetMinimalistic3

reset/CssResetPoorMan.html.title: CssResetPoorMan

reset/CssResetShaunInman.html.title: CssResetShaunInman

reset/CssResetSiolon.html.title: CssResetSiolon

reset/CssResetTantek.html.title: CssResetTantek

reset/CssResetUniversal.html.title: CssResetUniversal
reset/CssResetUniversal.html.body:
Usage
Simply render it in your React app
import CssResetUniversal from 'libreact/lib/reset/CssResetUniversal';



Contents
{
  '*': {
    'vertical-align': 'baseline',
    fw: 'inherit',
    ff: 'inherit',
    fs: 'inherit',
    fz: '100%',
    bd: '0 none',
    out: 0,
    pad: 0,
    mar: 0,
  },
}
